organization.fullName: VA Office of Research and Development

identificationModule.briefTitle: Diagnosis and Treatment of Sleep Apnea in Cerebrovascular Disease
identificationModule.officialTitle: Diagnosis and Treatment of Sleep Apnea in Cerebrovascular Disease

leadSponsor.name: VA Office of Research and Development

descriptionModule.briefSummary: Sleep apnea is common among Veterans with cerebrovascular disease (stroke or transient ischemic attack \[TIA\]), leads to hypertension, and is associated with recurrent stroke and death. Although continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) safely treats sleep apnea, few Veterans with cerebrovascular disease are diagnosed with sleep apnea or offered treatment.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: The project sought to evaluate whether a diagnostic and therapeutic intervention strategy among Veterans with cerebrovascular disease and hypertension using unattended polysomnography and auto-titrating CPAP with a targeted adherence evaluation and educational protocol resulted in: an improved rate of diagnosed sleep apnea, an improved rate of treated sleep apnea, and improved blood pressure control.

armGroups.label: Intervention
armGroups.description: The intervention group received unattended polysomnography and auto-titrating CPAP if sleep apnea was diagnosed
interventionNames: Procedure: CPAP Therapy for Newly Diagnosed Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA)

armGroups.label: Control
armGroups.description: The control group received usual clinical care which may include receipt of sleep diagnostic and therapeutic services
interventionNames: Procedure: CPAP Therapy for Newly Diagnosed Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA)

interventions.name: CPAP Therapy for Newly Diagnosed Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA)
interventions.description: Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) is provided for those patients who are diagnosed with OSA.

primaryOutcomes.description: The number of patients with a diagnosis of sleep apnea
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: The entire study period (baseline and up to one-year)

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

Stroke or Transient Ischemic Attack Hypertension

Exclusion Criteria:

* Prior diagnosis of sleep apnea or other sleep disorder
* Life expectancy \< 6 months or Hospice
* Non-English speaker
* Unable/unwilling to use mask
* Inability to give informed consent
* Oxygen dependent COPD
* Chronic renal failure with dialysis
* Active Suicidal Ideation

groups.title: Intervention
groups.description: The intervention group received unattended polysomnography and auto-titrating CPAP if sleep apnea was diagnosed

groups.title: Control
groups.description: The control group received usual clinical care which may include receipt of sleep diagnostic and therapeutic services

outcomeMeasures.title: Sleep Apnea Diagnosis Rate
outcomeMeasures.description: The number of patients with a diagnosis of sleep apnea
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The intervention patients had polysomnography at baseline (n=102) whereas control patients either had polysomnography as part of usual care (n=7) or at the end of the study as part of the study protocol (n=85). The n=7 patients who had polysomnography as part of usual care were included in the analysis for this outcome.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: The entire study period (baseline and up to one-year)

outcomeMeasures.title: Sleep Apnea Treatment Rate
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Among the 58 intervention patients with a diagnosis of sleep apnea, CPAP data were available for 57. Among the 7 control patients who received polysomnography as part of usual care, 5 had sleep apnea: CPAP data were available for 4 patients (2 did not receive any CPAP and 2 had CPAP therapy), the data card was unavailable for 1 patient.

seriousEvents.notes: new stroke event in patient with history of cerebrovascular disease
